Man, why Episode One is so much better than the original Half-Life 2? Having played Episode One, for me it became obvious that the vehicles sections are a useless filler and without it, Half-Life 2 would only win.

About this game:
A lot more dialogues, Alyx as a companion is great. A short, tense and more puzzle driven part of the Half-Life 2. I like this part. Enjoyed.

i dont know why people say episode one is the worst in the half life series, i dont personally think any half life game as of now is bad, episode one has more then just some New A.I and cut content added back, i wont spoile it to you, you have to play this, its good.

I love Half-Life and Half-Life 2, but Half-Life 2: Episode One, while fun, feels like a sub-par map pack. Overall this first Half-Life 2 expansion barely impacts the story (at least after the first two minutes) and most of the levels are below the average set by the base game. Still, this is well worth playing, if for nothing else to get to the much better Episode Two.

PROS:
- Great weapons and enemies from the base game
- Solid performance with no bugs encountered
- Great visuals with a few impressive moments
- Some difficult sections that surpass the base game's challenge
- First two levels are decent

CONS:
- Story seems like a step-down (even for its length)
- Level design does not meet the spec set by Half-Life 2
- Short even for the (non-sale) price

The weakest of the half life 2 epsisodes, but it still has it's strong points. It has the scariest horror segemnt from all the half life games (excluding alyx). "Well see about that"

As Freddie Mercury said, the show must go on. Half-Life 2: Episode 1, is a continuation after the events of Half-Life 2, a sequel if you will. However without revealing spoilers, you must play Half-Life 2 prior to playing this game. Episode 1 was met with overwhelming positive reviews and continues its high standing amongst the Half-Life saga as a noteworthy extension of brilliance.

Released two years after its predecessor in 2006, now in the form of an "episode" which Valve switched to, in other words an expansion. The game consist of the same authentic Half-Life mechanics, but focuses on the story between yourself the Freeman and Alyx. The game is updated in terms of the source engine, its AI component which reflects upon the behaviors of your foes including Alyx. I will applaud Alyx especially in this game as her artificial intelligence is greatly observed as a free will companion. 

The game includes the classical "chapters" and still, each chapter is  intense, eerie and atmospheric but contains heart pumping and well-paced action in line with its previous mentor. At times it shows the very essence of the half-life horror, when society is broken down, the sense of security is lost by all sides, all hell breaks loose and worlds collide.

Reminiscing is a word I tend to use whilst playing this game, as many references in many forms will always remind you of your past. You will be on your guard at times as you transverse the labyrinth before you. Listening to the slightest sounds, all alone in the dark with your torch. Is it a zombie? a head crab? and if so which type? and where will it strike?.. Does this not remind you of the quintessential Black Mesa?

The game is short and sweet if this is the ONLY negative that's perceived. But after all it is an expansion and its followed by Episode 2.

Still to this day, 16 years later, Episode 1 withstands the test of time and as always invokes that yearning sentiment in me for days gone by. I'm sure any gamer from the early days will agree..orange box anyone?

Enjoy!
